history.content:
I'm not sure if I fully understand your situation but Physics 7B pretty much admits everybody every semester. It's not an impacted class to get into :) 

I don't mean to be rude, but I disagree with the above student answer. Getting into 7B is not easy as a freshman/sophomore, and having a registration hold placed on you makes enrolling difficult even if you're a junior/senior. If need be I'm sure you can do 7B at community college and get it out of the way @OP

I'm not sure if I fully understand your situation but Physics 7B pretty much admits everybody every semester. It's not an impacted class to get into :) 

I don't mean to be rude, but I disagree with the above student answer. Getting into 7B is not easy as a freshman/sophomore, and having a registration hold placed on you makes enrolling difficult. The good news for OP is that there is an 8 AM section that will fill up later than others, and if need be I'm sure you can do 7B at community college and get it out of the way
I'm not sure if I fully understand your situation but Physics 7B pretty much admits everybody every semester. It's not an impacted class to get into :)

children.subject: Gone to the drop-in peer advising in ESS?
Have you talked to your ESS Advisor?
I second this. Take it at a CC, check assist.org to see if it counts, and you're off your way towards graduating in May.

You probably wont have any problems enrolling in 7B, but if you are really worried about it, have you considered taking the equivalency at a community college? There are a lot of community colleges that offer the physics 7B equivalent during their winter intersessions, so you could be finished with the requirement by early February. 

Here is a list of CCs with winter intersessions: https://www.cuesta.edu/student/documents/transfer_center/2018_Winter_Intersession_List.pdf 

You can check to make sure that you are taking an equivalent course at assist.org. Also, make sure that you talk to an advisor and verify everything.

history.content:
I am a senior currently taking 2 technicals and an H/SS + research units. I got an email today notifying me that I am out of the 2 tech compliance, which puts me on an indefinite hold for spring enrollment. Apparently, my second technical this semester does not count for the 2-tech policy because it is outside of the 20 units of upper div technicals I need to take (I have already completed 19 of these units prior to Fall 19). Thus, only one of my technicals count for this.

The only class I need to take to graduate is Physics 7B. Now I am on the verge of being put on hold for an indeterminate amount of time in Spring, potentially preventing me from graduating. How is this fair? I could have avoided this by only taking 2 technicals in Spring 19 instead of 3. But this means I am being penalized for taking a larger workload and trying to fulfill my requirements faster.

My future may potentially be ruined by this because I have accepted an offer to work full-time. My employment is contingent on my graduation in May 2020. Given my progress so far, it's obvious that I am on pace to graduate. But this hold now makes this an uncertainty. Is there any way around this? Can I nullify any of the units I have taken prior to this semester such that my 2nd technical can count? My advisor also does not have any advice other than to hope the hold does not prevent me from enrolling into 7B.

I am seriously concerned for my future right now. And this is taking a toll on my mental health.
history.subject: Out of 2 Tech Compliance (Might Not Graduate)

history.content:
I am a senior currently taking 2 technicals and an H/SS + research units. I got an email today notifying me that I am out of the 2 tech compliance, which puts me on an indefinite hold for spring enrollment. Apparently, my second technical this semester does not count for the 2-tech policy because it is outside of the 20 units of upper div technicals I need to take (I have already completed 19 of these units prior to Fall 19). Thus, only one of my technicals count for this.

The only class I need to take to graduate is Physics 7B. Now I am on the verge of being put on hold for an indeterminate amount of time in Spring, potentially preventing me from graduating. How is this fair? I could have avoided this by only taking 2 technicals in Spring 19 instead of 3. But this means I am being penalized for taking a larger workload and trying to fulfill my requirements faster.

My future may potentially be ruined by this because I have accepted an offer to work full-time. My employment is contingent on my graduation in May 2020. Given my progress so far, it's obvious that I am on pace to graduate. But this hold now makes this an uncertainty. Is there any way around this? Can I nullify any of the units I have taken prior to this semester such that my 2nd technical can count? My advisor also does not have any advice other than to hope the hold does not prevent me from enrolling into 7B.

Additionally, I had no idea this policy existed until now. Of course, I knew we had to be enrolled in 2 technicals but none of my advisors, faculty advisors, or any admin mentioned the fine print when I mapped out my course planned. I was never warned. How am I supposed to be aware of fine print like this when my advisors do not even warn me until its too late?

I am seriously concerned for my future right now. And this is taking a toll on my mental health.
